comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: See notes under en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yashiro_Rokur%C5%8D

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: The Maui news. (Wailuku, Maui, H.I.), 08 Oct. 1910, page 2, near bottom of middle column chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014689/1910-10-08/ed-... indicates that the Asami was a cruiser and a training ship.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: I had trouble finding the Asami, but what is apparently a typo in the Maui News article, coupling Asami with the cruiser Kasagi, led me to the Asama, which is most likely the ship depicted here. "Japanese cruiser Asama CareerJapanese Navy Ensign Name:Asama Ordered:1897 Fiscal Year Builder:Armstrong Whitworth, United Kingdom Laid down:1 November 1896 Launched:22 March 1898 Completed:18 March 1899 Decommissioned:30 November 1945 Fate:Scrapped 1947 General characteristics Class & type:Asama-class cruiser Asama (淺間?) was the lead ship of an early class of armored cruisers of the Imperial Japanese Navy. The ship was named after Mount Asama, located north of Tokyo." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japanese_cruiser_Asama

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content: artolog: Thanks for the extra digging. Agreed that this is actually the Asama rather than a ship called the Asami. Further support for that conclusion can be found in this illustrated article from the November 23, 1910 issue of The San Francisco Call, which shows both Yashiro and the Asama. We will update the record to correctly identify the ship and more fully identify Yashiro as well.
